Package stincmale.ratmex.doc

Annotation Type Immutable


  • @Documented
@Target(TYPE)
@Retention(CLASS)
public @interface Immutable
    An object of a type annotated with this annotation is immutable, the type is also called immutable. Immutable objects are inherently thread-safe.

    • When this annotation is applied to an interface it means that implementations of the interface must be immutable. If an implementation of the interface is not immutable, this must be explicitly stated (e.g. by annotating it with @NotThreadSafe). One should never apply this annotation to an interface unless there is a very good reason for this.
    • When this annotation is applied to a not final class it may mean either of the following and must be further clarified by the class:
      • Subclasses of the class must be immutable. If a subclass is not immutable, this must be explicitly stated (e.g. by annotating it with @NotThreadSafe).
      • The class is immutable, but it does not impose this restriction on its subclasses. This interpretation must not be used by not final not abstract classes.

    Immutability of an object means that its state cannot be seen to change by a user(1). Of necessity (but not sufficient) this means that

    • all public fields are final;
    • all public final reference fields refer to immutable objects;
    • methods do not publish references to any internal state which is mutable by implementation even if not by design.

    Immutable objects may still have internal mutable state (e.g. for purposes of performance optimization); some state variables may be lazily computed, so long as they are computed from immutable state and that users cannot tell the difference(2)

    References to immutable objects may be passed between threads (published) without any additional synchronization on the part of a user.

    Immutable objects must not be confused with read-only objects, which do not allow changing their state directly via their API but still may display mutability of the state (e.g. an object returned by Collections.unmodifiableCollection(Collection) cannot be modified via its API, but because such an object is just a view of an original Collection, its state may be changed because of changes in the original Collection).

    No type can be considered immutable unless the type is explicitly documented as such (e.g. it is annotated with @Immutable), or immutability of the class follows of necessity from some well-known truth.

    (1) By "use" we mean any interaction with an object via its API. Interactions via any other means (e.g. via Java Reflection) is out of the scope of this specification. Using a reference to an object (e.g. passing it between threads) is not considered to be a use of the object and generally requires an additional synchronization unless the object is immutable.

    (2) The paragraph is based on the Brian Goetz's very good specification of an immutable object from his book "Java Concurrency in Practice"
